Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing 125 I Seed and Hookwire Localization in Breast-Conserving Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Between September 2013 and March 2018, 690 women with non-palpable breast cancer eligible for breast-conserving surgery were randomised

Participants.evidence: 690 women with non-palpable breast cancer eligible for breast-conserving surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomised to preoperative localization using 125 I seeds or hookwires

Objective.evidence: aimed to compare re-excision and positive margin rates in breast-conserving surgery using 125 I seed versus hookwire localization

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were re-excision and positive margin rates, measured post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was stratified by lesion type and study site, with allocation concealed via a secure online database.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 690 women randomised, 659 were analysed

Result_Outcome.evidence: The re-excision rate was significantly lower in the 125 I seed group compared to the HWL group (13.9% vs. 18.9%; p = 0.019).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included suboptimal positioning requiring corrective action in 9 cases for seeds and 13 for wires.
